reviewText:
List price: 99.98
Release Date: Dec 2
Info:
*Alien can be watched in the original version or the new director's cut now playing in theaters.
* The 1986 sequel, Aliens, is available on DVD for the first time, with director James Cameron's special edition as well.
* Alien 3 (1992) has more than 30 minutes of new footage.
*Alien Resurrection (1997) has alternate opening and ending scenes.

Ok, for those of you who don't know what this Quadrilogy is, it is simply the 25th anniversary edition of the films. This boxset has the newest version of Alien: Directors cut, Aliens: Special Edition, Alien 3, and Alien Resurection. The first two Alien movies were the best in my opinion and last two were somewhat lacking in what made this seris so popular amoung Sci-Fi freaks in the first place. This item should be available for purchase before this Christmas and will be packaged in a boxset similar to the Alien Legacy. For those of you who have the Alien Legacy you are the lucky few who will be able to remember what the original version of the film looked like. For those of you who waited to grab the Alien Legacy (bet you are punching yourselves) here is your chance to own some of the best Sci-Fi movies that have ever been made. Pick this boxset up, you'll be pleased, I promise. 'Nuff said

The Box is arrived a little beat up but hey that's just because this is an old release. This is the best release of the Alien series due to the fact that it brings a massive amount of extras compared to other releases.

These movies are all that need to exist, I love the first two and don't despise the last two in this collection. Avoid the Prometheus and covenant movies...so dang dissapointed. Almost kingdom of the crystal skull dissapointed.

Blu-ray disks, all 4 movies: Aliens 1979/2003-Aliens 1986/1991-Alien 3 1992/2003-Alien Resurrection 1997/2003, carboard sleeve, 8 versions

Special Features: MU-TH-UR Mode Interactive Experience wit datastream of production notes and historical facts, all movies contain full length audio commentary, behind the scenes featurettes, 12k photos and artwork stills,  isolated scores w/ alternate and unused cues, archival documentaries, test footage, tv specials, multi-angle studies

This is a great collection of the original 4 films, plethora of special features & behind the scenes footage.

My only real fault was the way the discs are held in the set, it's easy for them to slip out and move. However, I've not experienced any issues (loose or scratched discs). But something to be noted.
The movies keep freezing while playing. Ruins immersion/suspense.

I bought the Alien Anthology because I had never seen any of the Alien movies and I heard they were great.  After watching all of the movies a couple of times, I can definitely say that the Alien franchise is one of my favorites.  Alien and Aliens are fantastic.  Alien 3 is pretty good.  Alien: Resurrection is maybe not good in the way the others are, but it's definitely a guilty-pleasure for me.  I say this was definitely worth the purchase.

according to a Alien Anthology review the Bluray contains:

Disc 3: Alien3
1992 theatrical version
2003 Special Edition (restored version)

31 deleted and extended scenes
MU-TH-UR Mode interactive experience with Weyland-Yutani datastream
Disc 4: Alien Resurrection

Audio commentary with director Jean-Pierre Jeunet, editor Herv Schneid, A.C.E., Alien effects creators Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff, Jr., visual effects supervisor Pitof, conceptual artist Sylvain Despretz, and actors Ron Perlman, Dominique Pinon and Leland Orser

With some flaws, it's still a GREAT buy for all that you get!

PRO'S:
Film transfers are really good, if not great. The DTS sound is also really good.
As for extras, Disc 6 is AWESOME, with archival footage from the laserdisc extras to storyboards, and tons more!

CON'S:
Sometimes I had to unplug & reset my blu ray player to get some of the discs to play.
Disc 5 of the extras is SO blurry it's a complete disaster of a transfer! If you have the DVD versions, stick with those!
I already exchanged the set with Amazon, but the 2nd set for Disc 5 was the same. The reps at Amazon were REALLY understanding, and documented the situation.

Discs 1-4 review (2 versions of each film):
* I viewed the extended versions of each film, except Alien because I found the addded scenes just slowed the pacing too much.

Disc 1- Alien:
As for picture clarity, you can see just about every pore & sweatdrop! There is some blur left in the picture, but I'm guessing that's for effects reasons. Overall, the transfer is great picture & DTS sound!

Disc 2- Aliens:
I choose the 'Special Edition' version because I like the extra footage added to the film.  For the 'added scenes' the volume is a little lower than the rest of the film, but it's not too bad. The picture clarity is good, although a little lower than Alien at times, but still pretty good. I thought the DTS sound to be a bit better than Alien.

Disc 3- Alien3:
In the DVD version they added the deleted scenes dialouge with subtitles because of very poor dubbing.
In this blu ray version the dialouge has been  restored to a complete 'Director's version'' witth no subtitles, which is really nice- although (like in Aliens) at times the dialouge does need some 'boosting', and is at a lower volume than the rest of the film. The color is a bit washed out a times, the effects really need a boost- too mush rotoscoping & shadow to be realistic. I liked how you get 2 versions of the Alien's birth too.
All in all not a bad film to the series, although a bit slow on the pacing at times. The DTS was good all in all.

Disc 4- Resurrection:
The lease impressive of the transfers for picture- a lot of the time it's dark & grainy, It's better than the DVD, but still looks like it needs color correction. The DTS sound is very good, though.

U[date for Disc 5- I called Fox Customer Care and explained the situation to the representative.
She said they didn't have any complaints from anyone, and their policy was to offer an exchange (the full set for a full set), which can take weeks.
I just decided to keep it, since I have all of Disc 5 on my double DVD set of movies.

This review is for the Alien Anthology box set, not the Alien Quadrilogy.

I've gone through 3 of these now and they've all had very scratched up discs. I think this is because of the way they're packaged. The discs are tight in cardboard sleeves so that when you pull them out they rub against the rough cardboard. Now why they're scratching so easily is another question, Blu-Rays are typically very scratch resistant. I've actually tested this out on some Blu-Rays before and couldn't even scratch them with my fingernails, I had to use sharp metal. So I think the issue here might be less the cardboard packaging and more an issue with the coating on the discs. Just get the quadrilogy set if all you care about are the movies because that's in a normal blu-ray case. If you want the additional material then I guess you're out of luck.

This remastered set is the bomb. Played on my UHD 4K tv the new detail and upscaling is phenomenal. Having alternate and director's cut versions is an added plus. I've never been a fan of Alien 3 or Resurrection but at least they look a lot better on this set.

Although they're more of a cult classic than a box office topper. All-in one, no frills box is exactly what we wanted. The second movie is still my favorite.

This Blu-Ray collection is excellent. There are 4 movie discs & 2 discs of extras. Each movie disc contains the original & SE movies.

However the the paper product book/case was poorly constructed & the double cardboard like pages/disc holders easily separated. I minimized that issue by wrapping the pages close to the spine with clear packaging tape.

All in all. I am happy with the price & product.

I always tend to feel the first story is the best. This quadrilogy, to me, lays the history of Ripley & her arch-enemy. This set came to me (as promised) in mint condition telling the respective stories as I remember them. The subsequent bells & whistles can come to me later. The images  are very sharp; some things I saw in the Cineplex are now recognisable...sweet! If you enjoyed Alien, I believe you'll love this set.

There aren't many special features in this quadrilogy version. I just wanted a high definition, extended cut of each movie that I could watch to refresh my memory in anticipation of the new movie. Worked great for that purpose!

Would give five stars if stickers and labels weren't placed directly on the gorgeous paper/cardstock slip cover. I hate to be nitpickiny  but I just can't stand ripped labels paper and residue. Other than that, love the set came in great condition.

So far everyone gave the movies 5 stars, don't get me wrong it is a total steal for all 4 movies on Blu Ray. But my biggest concern was when opening the box and pulling each disc out for checking. I saw a scratches and smudges on literally all the discs....luckily the first one is playing but it did take some time for my PS4 to even read it.....anyways Ill update if any of the other 3 discs fail due to scratches and random finger smudges....like come on...still a steal for 30 I suppose. And ask if you want photos.

For example, people complained about not getting the 2 extra disks, but the Alien Quadriology only includes the 4 blue ray disks, both extended and theatrical versions only as one guy pointed out. Its the Alien Anthology That has the 2 extra disks. I must say the presentation of the box is quite nice. Each blue ray disk is in its own special sleeve along with the illustration of that movie. It also has codes for all the alien movies to be viewed digitally and a code for a sneak peek at aliens covenant. But man the really stuffed this thing tight in the box itself, you almost have to shake it out. I really like the aliens series, and this Anthology collection is great for any alien fan. This is one of my favorite  franchises.  One of the few out there were the sequel was as good as the first (the rest were all mediocre, but I still enjoyed them).  I've had the first 4 on DVD for a long time now, but someone said they wanted to see Alien for a movie night.  So I searched, and to my surprise found 4 of them with 2 extended versions for just $15!  (I would have rather had it in 4k, but it's not out there yet).  Alien may be one of the scariest, most suspenseful films made (haven't watched the directors cut yet).  It's follow up, Aliens, is one of my favorite movies. It falls more into the "action" category than "suspense" (which is more my cup of tea).  If you've seen it 100 times like I have, you get something from the directors cut.  Gives you a little more insight into character development (don't want to spoil anything).  The other two films are ok, but not nearly as good as the first two.  They are both watchable, but really don't stand up to the first two (I enjoyed resurrection more than 3).  If you haven't seen these, for $15, it's a must buy!  Then if you really like it, you can get all the others (AVP, AVP Requiem, Prometheus, and now Covenant).

The disc menus look nice, stylized after the computer systems of the movies, though they are a bit clunky to navigate. At first I thought that there were no audio commentary tracks, but I just needed to scroll past all of the different language tracks. Why the commentary isn't listed immediately after the English audio is strange to me. The only reason I buy physical copies of movies is for audio commentary and special features so I am happy with this.

If you're a fan of the Alien saga and have an appreciation of director's cut movie editions, this is the collection for you. It's interesting to watch the original theatrical release and then watch the director's cut to check out the subtle (and not so subtle) differences.

Alien Quadrilogy 4 DISC blu-ray, verified purchaser. First, I am a huge fan ever since I saw Alien the first night it hit the theaters in '79 and will leave the actual movie details to others. This Alien Quadrilogy is the 4 Alien movies, each with the theatrical and extended editions only, No extra disks, the only extras would be what was included in the single blu ray releases. This presentation is in a thin line snap case, not a cardboard box. Now that I got that out of the way, here are my 2 complaints: First, since Amazon, for years being completely incapable of separating the reviews of all the different Alien releases (as so with with ALL other releases).the reviews below are mixed with ALL the different releases of the franchise and who, except for the most knowledgeable of this franchise, can tell the difference? Maybe we, as reviewers, should identify what it is we are actually reviewing, to help others. Hence, the 1 star ding. Second, specifically to this QUADRILOGY, the product details correctly identify this as 4 disks, which is correct, however, the Editorial review incorrectly claims 2 extra disks of over 50 hours of extras which is WRONG. Those extra disks are in the blu ray release of the Alien ANTHOLOGY, NOT this Quadrilogy. The transfers of the films themselves are the same as ALL other blu ray releases, no matter what the release is called (30th anniversary, Anth, Quad, single release, etc, all the SAME) and I have no issue with that. I believe this is as good as it will ever get, even some future possible 4K cant undo the limitations inherent in the technology used in the original filming. As I said, big fan here, but be aware that you are likely reading a review for a future purchase that is not what you will be buying. Unfortunately, it looks like Amazon will never over come this massive inability, so life goes on. If all you want is the extended cuts of the 4 movies and are not interested in all the extras, for $15, This is easily the best deal you're going to get. And no HD downloads here either. Just FYI.....
8/24/17 update. As more and more 4K reviews are showing up, Amazon, STILL shows 4 K's as "blu-ray" without distinction. Sad...

When this wonderful 9disc quadrilogy released in 2003  two discs per movie + one addressing the whole franchise  as big a fan as Ive been over the past 37 years, I already had these films in special & standard editions. But this past month I decided it was time to acquire a used copy (eBay) to finally see the extended Assembly Cut for Alien3. Not to be considered a Directors Cut as David Fincher had a massive falling out with 20th Century Fox while creating this film, it is so much more than just added scenes, in many ways its almost a different movie.

Let me first admit that Ive never been a fan of either Alien3 or Resurrection. When they killed off Newt & Hicks (Billie & Wicks) they instantly lost credibility. So is this a better film, its hard to say, its definitely more interesting if a bit slower, and as much as I loathe reviewers telling me something is a must, if you are a real fan of the franchise this is worth checking out. As prison Warden Andrews would say, this is rumor control, here are the facts. I took the time to watch the theatrical version again before sitting down a couple nights later to the expanded edition. Here are my amateur observations, and if you desire a more literal *spoilerlaced* interpretation I would then direct you to 2003 Assembly Cut, Alien3 on Wikipedia.

This Amazon listing refers to run time as 155 minutes while Wikipedia lists it at 10 minutes less. Both websites agree that the theatrical version was 114 minutes so figure on getting 30 to 40 minutes of additional content.

First off, some of the deleted scenes didn't get the post production audio upgrades and a few subtitles are inserted making them more understandable. There is much more footage of the creature, which does not incubate in a Dog but in another 4legged member of Fury 161. The beginning is altered & expanded upon, there is a sizable section on capturing the beast, and so much more character development amongst the inmates. I believe the musical scoring has changed and the religious overtones definitely heighten the overall feeling of apocalypse for these fateful faithful inmates.

And here we may have some insight into the falling out between the Director & 20th Century Fox. Whereas the theatrical release never justified the death of Newt & Hicks, which felt hollow & cheap, this extended edition shows a much more artistically calculated risk, which I can appreciate. Better movie? Definitely different, and worth the time. One last thing, only one inmate survived this movie & a recently released hardcover Alien: The WeylandYutani Report has a neat 8page insert that is supposed to be excerpted from a book this fictional inmate wrote about his Fury 161 experience. It is titled Space Beast, which I believe was the first working name of the original Alien.

Alien and Aliens are hands down my favorite sci-fi movies of all time, so I may be a bit biased, but this is one of the best Blu-Ray sets I own.

PROS:
-Beautiful packaging, small and subtle, gorgeous artwork inside, won't stick out of your collection, but will *stand* out.
-Blu-Ray transfer is GORGEOUS, especially in Alien.  You'll have a scene on the Nostromo with the characters in the foreground and the picture is so crisp and clear you can read the screen readouts on the computer monitors down the hall.  Every inch of the sets, the costumes, and the special effects are amazingly sharp.
-Audio is fantastic.  I'm not an audiophile, but I felt it was very clear and balanced, never felt the dialogue was washed out for the action.
-TWO whole discs of making-of, behind the scenes, and artwork featurettes.  None of these feel like cheap padding to fill out a collector's edition.  All of the featurettes are interesting and informative.
-Excellent menu system
-Theatrical AND Director's Cuts of both Alien and Aliens.  Alien has a bit more footage, but Aliens has a full 18 mins extra, including a lot of added depth and backstory for a few of the main characters.

CONS:
-Contains Alien 3
-Contains Alien: Resurrection.

I specifically ordered product ASIN: B001AQO3QA
But I received the Ireland boxed library book set with the symbol of 18 on the front, with a code of X000RD7XMJ on the wrapper.
On one hand, this might be valued by others as a nicer collection to sit on a shelf or in a box. Its the Blu-Ray case inside a sort of fancy cardboard book sleeve.
On the other hand, in the "Live Extras" category it searches the internet for extras but states that they are not available for my region. Since viewing the material is the utility I actually purchased the Blu-Ray for, it upsets me that I can not utilize this feature in my 'region'. Perhaps just being denied something that is not there is an insult enough.

But mostly I'm bothered that Amazon lumps all 30+ versions of these randomized movie sets into a single item, where it really becomes a crap shoot of what item the seller is actually selling. I read a lot of reviews that clearly stated they were reviewing specifically a certain set, nearly all of the reviews are for different sets, and I started to realize that if I was going to get this 6 disc set for thirty bucks that I was going to have to trust the amazon ordering system to somehow give me what I wished for. Obviously I did not get the item advertised in the picture. (No 18 in the pic.) After talking with my brother, I realized the reason the Irish version is being sent out is that Ireland has the least corporate tax of all the nations.

On to the movies... severe spoilers if you haven't seen the movies ever.
Alien:
I just finished watching the 2003 director's cut of Alien, I watched it first, and although the picture quality is extremely superb, I also wish the set had the version with crappy film grain quality. With such perfect resolution, my teenagers saw the alien hiding instantly, where in the first version (being so grainy) it was still kind of hidden in the machinery and a shocker when you realize its starting to move. The one time the alien jump scares you, its laughable since you clearly see it poses in the same hysterical pose from all the movies and video games, which is not reaching at you, but actually a jester's pose or spirit fingers. The worst part is when Ash's head is removed and they clearly cut the film and replace the prop head with the actor's head, there is an actual gap in film footage. There was no moving a human across the scene to stop the disbelief. It was just "here's a movie prop", then black footage, "now here's the real actor's talking head". This seems out of character for the movie since so much work seemed to go into the face hugger's skin, coloring, and details and fleshy under mass, and Ash's face with his blood cleverly painted and splashed on, right down to the details of the alien's metal teeth.

I would really like to see a version where it became grainy when an alien was in the scene, or even when the crew could not see well due to being in a space suit or being too dark. The movie was so clear that I am beginning to wonder if the original film grain was an aftereffect for the first movie. haha... It would be really neat if you could mark certain scenes to being grainy or not, then watch the complete movie as you have marked it.

Anyway, I was hoping it would be a memorably scary movie for my teenagers, but seemed to be a laugh fest during. But at least after the movie, it was too scary to watch the second film for them. So... maybe it wasn't so horrible after all. I'll have to watch the theatrical version to see if the same mistakes are so horribly obvious.

Amazon combines all movie reviews together, rather than to specific products, so I ended up pretty confused as to which Quadrilogy I was actually buying. Plus, I paid $18 for it and then checked back a few days later and it was only $10just my luck.

Anyway, this review is for the 4-Disc DVD Quadrilogy with half the alien face on the cover.  I was under the impression that this set contained 2 versions of each film: The theatrical cut and a special edition.  However, not the case with this set.  It has the theatrical release for A1, A3, and A4, but a special edition of A2.  This was disappointing since on the 9-Disc Quadrilogy set, BOTH versions of the film were on a single DVD disc.
I'm not too bummed about missing out on the 50 hours worth of special features since I simply don't have time to invest in watching all that.

If you just want a bare bones DVD set of the Alien films I would recommend this for $10. If you want all the bonus features and duel versions of each filmsmake sure you are buying the correct set since they all apparently have the same name: Quadrilogy

Before getting this set I was unfamiliar with Alien3 and Alien Resurrection.  I know a lot of fans strongly dislike A3 so it's pointless to heap on more criticism, so I will just say it was one of the most unpleasant and abysmal sequels ever.  Thankfully Alien Resurrection flat-out ruled! The cloned Ripley is also fascinating to watch, and not just because she looks almost exactly like Glenn Danzig.  The acclaimed french director Jeunet seemed determined to beat Cameron at his own game: Not only does it surpass Aliens in terms of killer action, but steals some thunder from Titanic with stunning underwater sequences.
Excellent. It has extras, extended editions of each movie, and commentary. Hard to beat for that price!

Initially I was a bit hesitant about ordering this collector's set as I already own the 4 Film boxset and the price was a bit high. After have the item in my basket for quite some time I noticed the price had decreased and finally decided to take the plunge and make the purchase.

The item was well packaged and arrived safely with no damage, unlike two of my other parcels ordered on amazon I had received in the past. On opening the box the noticed the standard packaging, with the safety plastic to keep everything in place while in transit. Although a little smaller than I thought, the egg has a total height of +/-24.5cm (9.65inches).

The Blu-Ray discs are securely stored in the base in a nice booklet type case, and the artwork looks really amazing. The egg also lights up really nicely and uses 2x AA/LR6 1.5v batteries (included).

All-in-all this is a really awesome boxset and I would highly recommend it to any avid Aliens Fan / Collector.

I have made an unboxing video which you can view here:https://youtu.be/azobUBOTA4o

This item was mislabled.  While it is in fact the Alien Anthology, it is an import, and is stamped by the Irish Film Association.  As a result, the disks were not immediately playable.  I put them into my blu-ray player and the screen went black and then froze up.  I turned it off and then back on again, and my blu-ray player, a Panasonic, downloaded something and the film worked, but audio did not immediately work either.  I finally got it up and running and then noticed that there were small white and black flecks in the picture.

I popped in several other blu-rays, in an effort to troubleshoot the problem, and found that the Irish discs were the only ones that showed white and black flecks.  I have since tried to replicate the problem and it consistently manifests the same black and white flecks; I have tried it on several different displays and it is always the same.

I have contacted the seller and they promised to refund the purchase price, but stated that: "We're happy to accept your return, but wanted to help explain a few things to you.  We sells thousands of blu-rays a month, and we can assure you that literally 100% of all Blu-ray issues are the player itself. Samsung and Sony have very limited playbility in general and have the highest incompatibility with various collectible blu-rays. We have literally never seen a single defective blu-ray in over a million sold.  We're happy to accept your return."  Samsung and Sony have "very limited playability"?  Really?  The highest volume sellers - worldwide - have "very limited playability"?  Pfft, as if bro.  Moreover, I have a Panasonic blu-ray player, so not a relevant or factual comment.  And oddly, there is no mention of the "Irish Film Association" labeling all over the package.

Also worth note, I have Alien and Aliens on blu-ray - both coded for the U.S. - and neither show any of the artifacts that I noticed while using the Irish version...it is downright bizarre, and I wish that were not the case because I'd love to keep the set, but for $119.00 I am not willing to compromise.  Also, the import issue aside, the seller did provide a brand new unit, sealed in the box - for what its worth.

I responded to the Seller and stated that "yes, I would like to return it," but I have not heard back from the seller since our initial contact.  I will be filing a claim with Amazon to get my money back.

How many movie franchises can stake claim at having achieved such strong cultural significance and a redefinition of their respective genres that even seeing their weakest films can stimulate the imagination? Most franchises don't have that quality, but some of them do - the "Star Wars", "Back to the Future", "Indiana Jones", "the Lord of the Rings", "Harry Potter", even "the Matrix" sagas - all of them whose best movies have emotionally and intellectually resonated with the moviegoers and whose worst movies at least offer sporadic moments of brilliance - say what you want to about "Star Wars Episode I", which is admittedly awful, but you can't deny that pod racing sequence was a dazzler. And the car chase in the bloated "Matrix Reloaded"? Awesome! These movies, no matter their flaws and weaknesses, have become indelible monuments in popular culture - parodied, imitated, paid tribute to, certainly ridiculed but definitely not ignored and certainly never forgotten.

Joining that list of illustrious and indelible landmarks of pop culture is the "Alien" saga. Ever since Ridley Scott ripped John Hurt's heart out of his chest with the ferociously scary original, this saga continues to cause reverberations in the world of movies. Much like "Star Wars", which was a giant influence on the series, its impact on the public, in terms of storytelling, genre conventions and especially visuals, cannot be underestimated - not just movies, but comic-books, graphic novels, horror shows, video games, even paintings and architecture. if anything, the "Alien" saga seem tailor made for Blu-Ray. The details, the tiny nuances, the art direction, the subtle but expressive sound effects and the ruggedness of the human face, which was barely hinted in DVD, could finally be expressed on Blu-Ray and rightly so due to how much the "Alien" movies were visceral experiences visually and aurally. That's why the "Alien Anthology" was so eagerly anticipated when it came out back in 2009 and expectations were high as to rather the "Alien" movies could showcase what Blu-Ray could do in ways that DVD could not.

Now the question remains: is this set we've been waiting for? The answer is a resounding yes. "Alien" in particular looks absolutely stunning. The first time I saw it on a big screen, I couldn't believe how much detail I've discovered that I did not in the Quadrilogy DVD set. Just watch the opening sequence where the Nostromo computer awakens in this set and then compare it to the DVD version and the difference in quality and quantity are staggering; you'll discover tiny tidbits that you didn't notice in the DVD set. The blackness lurking within the corridors of the Nostromo no longer look overwhelming dark; there's various shades and shadow detail that make it feel like a retro tug boat, a compressed environment that is appropriate for a group of blue-collar workers to function in. The red blood that pops out of Kane's chest, the orange fire from the flamethrower, the white blood from Ash's carcass and the blue laser light that skims through the fog as Kane discovers the eggs are so strikingly vivid that they immediately stand out, which is what Scott intended. I can't imagine "Alien" looking better than it does now on Blu-Ray.

The picture quality in the three sequels are also excellent, albeit not as pristine as "Alien". When James Cameron revealed that he was going to de-grain and color correct "Aliens", several fans were understandably at arms as they felt this would distort the original look of the films. If there were any such negative changes, I didn't notice and thankfully "Aliens" looks exceptionally good and has very, very little of the ruinous plastic waxy look that we all feared it would have (anybody who watches the first Blu-Ray version of "Patton" will know what I mean). The fine detail, the balanced black levels, the strong colors and even moments of graininess are still prevalent and I didn't sense any blurriness often associated with DNR.

I could pretty much the say the same for "Alien 3" and "Resurrection", although both are marginally less impressive. Because both of them are generally disdained by fans, critics and even the studio executives who financed them, it's no surprise these two films doesn't score exceptionally high grades in the picture department. "Resurrection" definitely looks the best of the two, only because of Jean-Pierre Jeunet, who is a master at delivering stunning visuals and rich color palette, directed it. Still, the picture qualities for these films are overall very good and definitely a huge improvement over their DVD counterparts. If "Aliens" and the other sequels don't offer an impeccable visual presentation like "Alien", they are still leaps and bounds over the DVD versions.

Although all four movies differ in picture quality, they all sound equally sublime on audio. You haven't experienced the "Alien" saga until you've listened to them on the lossless DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 surround tracks. Holy Cow, was I was blown away? "Alien" has an eerie, unsettling sound design that was merely hinted in the DVD, but is stunningly rendered on Blu-Ray. Notice the contrast between the nearly deadening silence in space and the working mechanics operating in the Nostromo. The clanking of chains, the indelible drops of water in the ducts, the operative electronics in the computer system, even the alien's horrific screaming as Ripley tries to kill it in her pod, are pushed to the forefront, giving "Alien" an overwhelmingly frightening experience that has most likely never been felt since it was first released in theater. "Aliens" (and to a lesser extent, "Alien: Resurrection") takes a direct opposite: if "Alien" was as subtle as feather, then "Aliens" is as blunt as a sledgehammer. Pulsating gunfire, ear-shattering explosions, rampant footsteps and the alien's recognizable shrieking ignite the speakers at maximum volume, giving the impression of a horrific roller-coaster ride that you can't get off of. "Alien 3" sounds just as good, but best of all, it fixes many of the audio problems that bogged down the previous DVD copy. I think it's safe to say that "Alien" fans can finally retire their DVD copies for this new and improved Blu-Ray set.

But we're not done yet! I haven't even gotten started on the supplements. If you thought the "Alien Quadrilogy" on DVD was a monster, wait until you buy "Alien Anthology". It would literally take a week just to salvage through these bonus features, ranging from deleted scenes, storyboards, concept sketches to documentaries, production stills, trailer and TV spots, even parodies. As a bonus note, not only are all the DVD supplements from the previous set present, but the "Wreckage and Rage" documentary on "Alien 3" has been restored to its original length, which shows sections of director David Fincher having conflicts with studio meddling, something that didn't happen in the Quadrilogy set. I can't think of any Alien fan who would be displeased with what this set has to offer.

The "Alien Anthology" is not only worth the wait, but worth buying a Blu-Ray player for. If you don't have the set already, what the heck are you waiting for? Stop reading this review and go buy it. If you thought you've fully experienced this saga before, wait till you purchase this set. In space, no one can hear you scream. But in your house, they will certainly hear you jump in joy as you've experienced the "Alien" movies like none other.

This review is for the 6-disc Blu-ray anthology imported from the U.K. The current price for this anthology makes it well worth buying versus getting the first two separately. It's generally accepted that "Alien" (first film) directed by Ridley Scott was the unique ground-breaking Sci-Fi horror film. The second, directed by James Cameron (of Titanic and Avatar fame), is considered as good as the first. The third film had a very young David Fincher in his directorial debut and the franchise ran into some trouble. It's not Fincher's doing as much as it is the turmoil the production had been in for a long time, compounded by incessant studio executive(s) meddling and overruling numerous Fincher creative decisions. Fincher subsequently directed Seven, The Game, Fight Club, Zodiac, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (U.S. remake), and most recently Gone Girl (not a comprehensive list). Alien3 did not fare that well with the critics but did OK at the box office. The fourth film, Alien: Resurrection was directed by a French director who spoke little English and used a translator. IMHO this was not conducive to efficient or effective film directing, and it shows. It employs a Deus Ex Machina scheme to resurrect Ripley who had killed herself in Alien3. It saw a modest improvement with the critics and also did OK at the box office. Even if the ending of the 4th didn't some finality, It was clear the franchise had exhausted itself. (The Alien vs Predator spin-off from the Alien and Predator franchises hopes to breath some life into the two as a single franchise with its own arc.) The 3rd and 4th are not up to the power of the first two, but they're not complete dogs albeit getting the Ripley arc into the 4th one was contrived.

Bottom Line:
Alien and Aliens (the first two), with Alien3 and Alien: Resurrection as full-length film bonus features, all at a good price, with two additional discs of additional bonus material related to all four films.

(Two Important Notes-
 First: This is a review for the Blu-Ray "Alien Anthology" boxed-set.  Amazon seems to have lumped together the reviews of this set with previous boxed-sets.
 Second:  I do not own any prior DVD or Blu-Ray release of the series.  So I cannot compare this set to any prior sets/releases.  This is merely a stand-alone review of this specific boxed-set.)

The "Alien Anthology" Blu-Ray boxed sets is one of the most satisfying buying experiences I've had this year as a horror/sci-fi fan.  It's a great value for a collection of great films, and is definitely worth buying for fans who either don't already own the films, or are looking to upgrade their DVD's to Blu-Ray without breaking the bank.

The set includes the first four "proper" films from the "Alien" franchise (Alien, Aliens, Alien 3, Alien: Resurrection), each with two versions (original theatrical edition and alternate versions), commentary tracks, an interactive viewing mode ("Mu-Th-Ur Mode") plus two discs of rather comprehensive and interesting bonus content, including hours of making-of documentaries, thousands of behind-the-scenes photos and more.

The packaging is quite nice, though somewhat problematic.  The set includes a nice, glossy cardboard sleeve that serves as a cover to a miniature "hardcover book" inside.  The discs are housed in smaller sleeves, which serve as the "pages" for the books.  The set itself is quite compact, yet looks good, especially when sitting on a shelf, and the "book" has some nice artwork inside.  The only real issue is that because the discs are housed in "sleeves", I feel like there's the slight potential to pick up tiny "scratchies" if they are frequently removed/put back in.  But it's not too big a concern, so long as you're careful when removing/placing the discs back.

For only about $25, this is definitely a great set to buy, especially as at stores, the individual films are generally anywhere from $8-$15 a piece.  (Generally falling into the $10 range, it seems.)  Definitely a good cost-saver, as it could save you a bit of money depending on where you shop.

I would highly recommend this release.  I'm a fan of the franchise who had never had a chance to own any prior DVD/Blu-Ray releases, and I'm quite happy with this set, especially for the price.

(Edit:  I have had some skipping issues with Disc 2- "Aliens."  But it's not consistent, so I cannot tell if it is a fault of the disc or my player.)

The films themselves are fantastic - I include Aliens 3  in this, even if David Fincher the director doesn't like it - I like everything he touches, so, yeah.

The bigger story here is the presentation on Blu-Ray. You can see these films on TV, you can stream them online, you can buy them on a DVD disc. So why shell out the extra cash to buy these films on Blu-Ray? That's what I'm hear to argue for.

Firstly, Blu-Ray has superior image quality to DVD, even your cable provider and Netflix may say it's a 1080 image but the quality is far compressed compared to Blu-Ray. And with everyone owning a big screen TV, it's impossible to argue for anything less than Blu-Ray quality.

Not only do Blu-Rays have superior visual (and audio) quality - the discs can fit more features. In the case of this package, they use everything they can.

Each film's disc has it's own commentary tracks and various special features. But in addition to what they fit on each films disc there is MORE content about the films on the last two discs. You can choose to watch the movie is MU-TH-UR mode which allows you to bookmark parts of the film that have accompanying special features on the last two discs. You need a USB port on your Blu-Ray player so MU-TH-UR mode can store each of the bookmarks on the USB drive. When you put in either of the last two discs, you can jump right to the feature you were looking for while watching the film. And there are a LOT of features to get through. Hours and hours of them - literally.

Aditionally, the discs may all have the FBI and copyright warning in the beginning but if you put one movie in with a USB drive, it remembers you sat through those warnings once and will automatically skip the warnings on the other discs!

My only complaint about this set is how the discs are stored. You slide them out of a hard cardboard "page" in a book of discs. That means the information side of the disc is constantly rubbing against something and that greatly worries me about scratches.

Weyland-Yutani Corporation: "Building Better Bluray Collections" : )

This is the best movie collection I own.  I've never put a photo in a review before (they're crappy camera shots, sorry), but I was so happy with this one I just had to.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
-The movies are great first of all.  Each one comes with the option to watch the original - OR - an updated version/directors cut.  Each disc gives you the standard blu-ray menu you'd expect; such as 'play' 'options' etc etc.

- Presentation is amazing.  I love that we get a book inside of an outer case.  Within the book there's artwork.  This is really high quality, the "pages" are extremely thick and the outside of the "book" has the feel of a hardcover novel.  There is holographic art on both the outer shell and the book itself.

- Formatting and questions about region lock (seen in other reviews).  I am a US user and watch this on a playstation 4.  I specify this as your bluray player may be different.  All of the discs play and when I look on the bottom of the box I see FBI warnings and markings traditionally seen in the USA.  HOWEVER, there also appear to be european ratings listed as well.  Seems to be formatted for multiple regions, but for more techincal answers on this you should seek advice from other reviewers.  I'm not too savvy with that.  The movies play for me.

the QUADRILOGY is only 4 discs on flip trays of 4 films with the audio commentaries added for each film
and the theatrical trailers of each film that's the only extras any fan will get
a waste of time reissue in my opinion another eg of 20th century fox just trying to make a quick buck
and not caring about the quality of the product
if you don't have it already then buy the 2010 ALIEN ANTHOLOGY set which is 6 Disc set in thick blu-ray case

which does have all 4 films with both versions of each film
plus has all the making of Documentaries & featurettes, stills Photo Galleries, archive featurettes of each film on Disc 5 & 6
worth every Dollar to buy the now 7 year old ALIEN ANTHOLOGY
the reissue is worth nothing, 1 star for the reissue, 5 stars for the 2010 Anthology

I find it odd that I can write a review of an item that we cannot buy yet.  Amazon, how is it fair to a product manufacturer when anyone can write a review here without actually experiencing it, potentially impacting the sales of said item?

That being said, based on the Alien Quadrilogy description, and owning the earlier Alien Anthology Blu-ray set myself, Anthology seems to feature the same movie discs as the Quadrilogy.  This Alien Quadrilogy set simply delivers the best versions of these movies without any bonus material or digital versions.  Assuming the picture and sound quality are the same as the Alien Anthology, then Aliens fans won't be disappointed. The Quadrilogy is ideal for people who don't need hours of extra content, documentaries, etc.  Not having these doesn't make the product bad because it's not claiming to have any of that.  If you want the extra content, then get the Anthology set.

I remember Aliens: The Special Edition on laserdisc being over $100.00 back in the day, and that was for one movie.  So, if you consider the volume of entertainment you get here with a state of the art presentation it's really far from a bad deal for about $30.00.  Also, the box art is great too; I'm almost tempted to buy this on that alone. The only major flaw I see in this set is the lack of digital copies so that these films can be enjoyed on multiple platforms especially when that's a pretty common feature these days.

I was extremely excited to watch the Aliens saga this weekend once I got this in the mail. First disc worked flawlessly with no issues. However, the second disc for whatever reason glitches, skips, and pauses at an hour into both theatrical and special edition versions and will no press past. I thought it was my blu-ray player at first but I've never had any issues with watching movies on it before. I even went as far as to play it on another blu-ray player and it did the exact same thing. Disappointed in my purchase and hope they will fix whatever it is wrong with the 'Aliens' disc for future customers.

Update: Saturday Oct 18th @ 7:22 PM (CST)

Excellent costumer service for this issue, will update review upon receiving my refund and I will re-purchase this item. Hopefully it was a fluke set and my next set is better. Will also update once I receive the new set of blu-rays.

Update: 3 May 2015

So I received my refund from Amazon but during some cleaning and rearranging of my house I ended up moving my blu-Ray set and "losing it". Found it earlier this week and decided to try it out one last time before tossing it away. Now, I dunno if it was due to the heat that day or some other weird reason but my movies work flawlessly now. I kind of want to shove a foot in my mouth now because I was definitely upset when they didn't work the first time around. As of right now I'm watching my movies without a hitch. If you end up purchasing this PLEASE, get a good look at the back of your discs if they're free of scratching but look kind of odd, give it some time. At least that's what I did and now, almost 6 months later, I'm enjoying some badass sci-fi! FIVE STARS!
What can I say that hasn't been said? Great collection w/great video & sound & extras. A must for sci-fi movie lovers (Alien3 is not as bad as some would make it out to be).
Don't buy this. It's just the movies, none of the exceptional bonus features from the actual Alien Quadrilogy set. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE SKIP IT!

I would rate this Aliens collection an C- / D, or 2-stars, for lack of content for price.  Released on October 7, 2014, this Quadrilogy is missing all the bonus features of the previous Aliens: Anthology Blu-Ray set. Moreover, I found that this Alien: Quadrilogy was more expensive on Amazon than the 9-disk Aliens: Anthology on Amazon.

I feel scammed that they would release an inferior product at an increased price years after the Aliens: Anthology Blu-Ray.  In fact, there is no reason to get this collection at all.  This collection is merely a 4-disk set that contains the Theatrical and Special Editions of each movie, nothing more.

This Alien: Quadrilogy should've been much cheaper, thank you Amazon for already decreasing the price since my initial post of this review ;)

I will admit that I definitely love these movies.  Who would have thought that not only could you fit all of the special features of the Alien Quadrilogy on just two discs of utter mayhem.  Alien Quadrilogy: 5 discs of special features.  Alien Anthology Blu-ray: 2 discs of special features plus some extra goodies that aren't even in the DVD Alien Anthology such as the Family Guy Alien Parody and the Alien Parody from Space Balls.  The first movie will always be the best one.  It almost feels like the theatrical version of the first one is always scary to me.  I think zooming in on that cat when one of the characters gets killed by the Alien is beyond superb.  Mind you, there's only one Alien and several crew members, so it knocks the pants off of anyone who watches it.  However, the director's cut jolts it up several notches and I absolutely love when Ripley sees the Alien cocoon scene.  Absolutely superb.

Then we have the beyond amazing Aliens.  I absolutely love what James Cameron did with the Alien Queen.  This movie is by the far the best in the series.  It takes place nearly 60 years after the first film, even though the sequel is only a 7 year difference between the release date of the original film.  Every character is well loved to me in this film.  Then we get to see Ripley take on the Alien Queen and a hoard of Aliens.  What more could you ask for?  This is also the beefiest of the films clocking in at 2 hours 35 minutes.  I also think the little girl in the film is well casted.  There isn't anything wrong with marvelous movie.  Probably the only thing wrong I can think of is that the theatrical cut should have been  what the extended cut is.  This movie originally got slammed for its long length and was cut by 17 minutes.  James Cameron should have just stuck by his gun caliber and made the extended cut the theatrical cut.  Other than that, brilliant movie.

In all honesty, the 3rd Alien film could have been better.  Don't get me wrong, I love this movie to pieces.  I think it offers up an interesting premise to make our Alien villain a four legged monster this time.  I don't know where the idea came from to make the supposedly last Alien film be in a prison.  I get that Sigourney Weaver wanted to have an Alien kill her at some point.  I think she mentioned at one point that she thought it would be cool if an Alien were inside of her at one point in the story.  Well, she got her wish.  This story does make a great movie with a very dark premise.  The prisoners are crazy mad and that's the way I like them.  I do like that the prisoners fight with their lives to kill the four legged Alien.  The difference between the theatrical cut and the director's cut will astound anyone.  The theatrical has a dog.  The director's cut has a steer.  Both die in mostly the same way.  They said on the special features that they couldn't figure out a way to make the Alien move in the director's cut section, so they wound up going with a dog instead.  It is a very great film.  The only thing that I don't like is that Ripley has to die in the final part of the movie.  You've created such masterpieces with the two original films, why kill off the main character?  It reminds me of the way with T2 Judgment Day.  When I was a kid, I cried when the Terminator character had to die in the 2nd film.  And I felt the same way about Ripley in the Alien 3.  Its an emotional thing I deal with every time I watch the 3rd film.

Have no fear, Ripley returns in the 4th Alien film in the franchise.  I think Sigourney Weaver does an excellent job in the 4th film.  Sure, it isn't the best film, but it does offer up plenty of goodies that make it essential to the Alien films.  I would say that this film offers up a horror/action mash up.  It kind of takes inspiration from Aliens from the 2nd film.  Not in full, just with the aliens factor.  Multiple creatures.  In all honesty, this fourth film offers up some quirky comedy which always makes me laugh.  Never hurts to have comedy in a horror movie.  The Aliens take on a more dinosaur look in this film which is okay.  Just don't go too far away from the original design.  The men offer up plenty of testosterone for everyone to enjoy.  I also love how they decided to go with a female android which is a very nice touch to the robots.  I also love Ripley's comment about what kind of model they created, which always makes me laugh.  Just watch it in the movie, its during the time when the female android connects herself to a bible that manually controls the ship.  She makes for an interesting robot.

Now, I will finish off with the bad stuff, which is how much I had to pay for this.  I was probably one of the many who bought this set of movies on Blu-ray when it first came out.  This means that anyone who didn't wait to purchase it had to pay over $100 for a set of movies that are now at 30 some dollars.  You see, I went to purchase this from FYE, which I admit is an expensive store to begin with.  (For Your Entertainment).  I was originally expecting to have to pay $140 just to get these movies.  I knew right then and there that if the movie did in fact cost that then I would have wiped out my entire allowance from a single purchase.  However, that wasn't the case.  FYE had it on sale for a discount price and after I signed a membership that I canceled after I bought the movie made the movie only $107.  Consider yourselves lucky if you're now just thinking about purchasing these movies.

Regardless, be happy about these films.  This thing offers so much special features in those two special feature Blu-ray Discs that it blows my mind.  It has everything from Alien Quadrilogy and more.  I hope you make the right decision and purchase these movies.

the alien anthology blu ray. yes. i bought this from amazon and it came in 3 days before it said it would, so that was pleasing. This box set has 6 discs. One for each film aswell as two special features discs. The first disc (which was alien) has the theatrical and 2003 special edition versions. The same for all the other films aswell as a couple of comentaries and an isolated score track for each. The special features discs were one for the making of all the films and the other for concept art and other stills frok the making of each movie. The documentaries for making each film range from 1.30 to 2.30.  These documentaries cover the story creature design, and to release aswell as some other things. For example, for aliens it had a featurette on the power loader vs. the queen fight. the stills and art work are exetensive from designing the astronaut suits an space ships to the aliens themselves. It all comes in a hardcover book with the discs in each page and a couple of stills and info about each movie. On the following page, it has a cool picture from the movie. For example, for alien, it showed the space jockey (engineer) and aliens showed the queen fighting ripley. it all goes in an elusive and shiney case wit the xenomorph roaring on it. Ths is a must own for any alien fan and someone who wants to get sucked up into an iconic universe. buy it. period.

I recently purchased a PS3 for the bonus of using it as a Blu-ray player, so I set out to purchase the Blu-ray versions of many of my favorite, classic Sci-Fi films.  As the title of my review suggests, I already own the Alien Anthology DVD Edition, so I wanted to compare between the two for quality, which is why I gave it 5 stars.  At the time I have posted this review, the Blu-Ray version is also incredibly cheap already for such a new release (2013) while the DVD version was released in (2010) - far cheaper than when I originally purchased the DVD Edition a few years ago.  However, both are about the same price point now depending on sales.  The extra money IS worth it for the Blu-Ray version if you have the means to play them.

My review also contains below my thoughts on each film as well if you prefer an opinion if these films are even worth watching (if you are a first time viewer).  And also, if one is deciding whether or not to watch the "theatrical" release or "director's cut" first of each film.

IMAGE QUALITY:

- Outstanding

While the DVD version is already pretty decent, the Blu-Ray version of each of these films are definitely high-quality.  A lot sharper detail on everything.  There are definitely areas of scenes that were far more clearer, especially for background area, compared to the older VHS, and then transition to DVD.

SOUND QUALITY:

- Excellent

Again here, my opinion is that the sound has improved slightly from the DVD version.  This Blu-Ray version specifically has cleaned up audio on some of the films such as the Alien 3 Director's Cut DVD.  The original Alien 3 Director's Cut DVD had input alternate or new scenes, but the audio that was spliced in was extremely quiet - it was so queit they put text on the TV so you could actually hear what they are saying for specific extra scenes.  On the Blu-Ray version its not a problem at all, you can hear them perfectly and they removed the automatic subtitling from those scenes.

OVERALL PACKAGE:

- VERY good

Plenty of extra's, all of the director's cut and theatrical releases are available in high quality, you can also watch them with commentary on or off, and there is also another disc that delves into the Alien Universe.

THE FILMS:

My first recommendation is to watch all of these in order, to really get a sense of the beginning of the film that definitely defined true Horror combined with Science Fiction.  No doubt, these films gave me nightmares when I was child.

Alien (Must See) - Where it all started and while it is old, it has stood up to the test of time with a sense of 'believability' despite the old technology used to make the film.  You'll feel like you are watching real people on a space ship that are exploring planets.
------
*Should I watch the Theatrical or Director's Cut first?  I recommend watching the Director's Cut -- The extra scenes do 'add' to the film's original plot, rather than becoming distractions.  But do definitely watch the Theatrical release to see the difference and decide for yourself.

Aliens (Excellent) - The nightmare is back for Ripley and this time its payback.  The character is a strong-willed survivor that really shows that Female Heroines are needed in more films and stories.  You might be thinking, well Ripley has backup this time, so maybe nothing too bad will happen, right, RIGHT?  But most people already do know if they haven't seen it already ;).  I think the premise of these films is more believable in confronting an unknown horror, while not invincible, the Aliens (or "xenomorphs") of this fictional universe are deadly efficient and do not give up.
------
*Should I watch the Theatrical or Director's Cut first?  DEFINITELY watch the Director's Cut first - again, the extra scenes do add to the overall arcing story rather than significantly altering anything.  Watch the Theatrical Release to see the difference.

Alien 3 (Very Good) - Controversial for many fans, as many film goers or avid book readers are used to the Hero or Heroine and their friends having a perfect ending, which is a common "trope" of stories.  This film takes that idea and turns it upside down, because this is the Alien Universe after all.  Not everything turns out perfect in our world or a fictional world, and certainly not a fictional universe with aliens such as Xenomorphs.  As I said with "Aliens" - Xenomorphs are relentless, emotional, nightmarish creatures that will do anything to propagate its species like an overgrown parasite.  For those that have seen it, they will know exactly what I am referring to, but I do not want to spoil it for those that have not seen it.  For what's it worth, I think the setting is perfect and conducive to the dark, creepy settings of the first two films and the ending is also good, with a sense of relief for the main character (The Nightmare feels like it is finally over).
------
*Should I watch the Theatrical or Director's Cut first?  For this one, I have to say that the Theatrical release SHOULD be watched first.  The Director's Cut is essentially an ALTERNATE movie with different events taking place, while its 'ok' in its own right, the Theatrical release feels more appropriate to the continuity of watching each film in succession.  DO watch the Director's cut after to see the difference.

Alien 4 or "Alien Resurrection" (Fair/Good) - I have always had mixed feelings about this film, as is common for many other fans of the series.  The setting is great, but the writer (Joss Whedon) often input satirical components into the Alien Universe, which felt out of place.  There is a joke, for instance, in the film (SPOILER?) where the always "up to no good" corporation "Weyland Yutani" (which any reader should or viewer of all of the 3 previous films should know by now) is "bought up by Wal-Mart."  Its one of those moments where you kind of just have to laugh at the absurdity of placing such a comment in a film like this.
The film itself still captures the horrifying feeling from the first 3 films and the specific effects are definitely great for both the new "CGI" Xenomorphs and the newest suits they used for the Xenomorphs.  However, the story itself takes out any of the mystery and "unknown" from the first films.  All in all - the film itself feels like a mess, and Ripley is deduced to a campy action hero, BUT the ACTING is plenty good for what it is.
------
*Should I watch the Theatrical or Director's Cut first?  I would have to say the Director's Cut in this instance, the original theatrical release (according to the director Jeunet who was already at odds with the writer Joss Whedon), was in essence the "actual" director's cut.  The extra scenes in the Director's scene do lend to try and connect Ripley to the former films.

So there you have it folks.  Its fairly cheap at the time I bought it and definitely a great addition for any movie collector, avid film watcher, or Sci-Fi Junkie.

You just have to love the Alien films, and this anthology is great, giving you all the films in one package in addition to being a good value

I got this set on the amazon daily deal for a good price. I like the book form packaging.this show be the norm. This saves space. I just don't know why you need 11 pages  for 4 movies and 2 bonus disc,5 are empty just pictures. This makes the book bigger than it has to be,just sayin', Anyway you have all the Alien movies except Prometheus.

LOVE this movie series and highly recommend!  This was made before cgi and the convoluted plots we have in modern movies.  One of the best movie series I've ever seen.  Special effects and plot are far superior to most movies today.
All the Alien movies you can ever want. I believe Aliens was the best of the series. I want to get a pet Alien monster.
I already had the anthology on DVDs.  Before that I had the individual movies on DVD.  Blu-ray is even better.

My husband and I (my hubby more than me) are fans of the series. We got a BluRay player last year for Christmas and are replacing all of our DVD's with BluRay titles. This was a great way to get more than 1 at a time. We only really like the first 2 movies though, hence the 4 stars.

I won't go into review of the movies as you can find that elswhere, but this is a great little package putting together the 4 primary Alien movies. We did a 4 night marathon and re-viewed some and other for the first time. The extended ("Director's Cuts") versions aren't typically much longer than the theatrical. Some of the directors mention they are just different versions, not necessarily their favorite cut but the studio wanted a "DC" version for the box set release. The extra features are decent, some novel, some take so long to load (the web based stuff) we gave up. They take a particularly long time to load on our NEW pan 3D players and generally require you to have a storage SD card on your B-R player to function. So be patient when first inserting/loading. They will load (5-8 minutes) and then they function fine. Kinda quirky but the rest is all good.

OMG, this set is off the hook! It is sharper than the theater screenings in '79 that I saw  9 times the year it opened.
Scott's 2003 cut is a masterpiece. Buy this and Prometheus on blue ray and you will have the definitive Alien collection.

The visuals and sound are great. I like how they provided each released version of the movies. If you are looking to upgrade from your DVD versions or just need to get the blu-ray version, don't hesitate.
The box set of all the movies was cheaper than the first two movies separately. This way you can enjoy the first two movies (and maybe the third), and you get a free coaster.
Great price Nd great entertainment. They don't make them like this anymore. Buy this while you still can. You won't be sorry
Can't beat what you get for the price.  This is easily the best disc collection of the Alien series. Just needs Prometheus.

I'm a huge fan of the first two in the Alien series, not so much for Alien 3 and 4.  But all the movies look great on Blu-ray, the sound is spectacular, and on a high-def LED TV, they appear better than when I saw them in the theater!  If the price is right, and you are a fan of these movies, I would recommend the Blu-ray versions of these classic Science Fiction movies.
all the movie's work well been wanting to get the set for some time looking foreword to heaving a movie night with friends to brag about them

Awesome movies, with great picture and sound quality. I received the booklet packaging, but I have seen pics of people that appear to be getting a different set than pictured. Awesome addition to any Scifi fans collection.

Excellent Alien compilation loaded with extras. I am well pleased with this anthology. All four movies are here, including several directors cuts. The description indicated that it is loaded with extras, that doesn't do it justice. It is jam-packed with them! This is a must for any Alien fan!
Just received and it looks perfect. My brother is a huge Aliens fanatic, and you can't beat that price for a blu-ray!  I'll definitely use this store again in the future :)

I bought this for my husband and he loves it! It is well made and excellent quality! perfect for a fan!

Amazing package and content. Tha package is outstanding and the content of the discs will ensure you many hours of viewing.

Not every Alien movie is a classic but for the price paid, who cares.  You get all of the films, cool extra's in a nice boxset.  It's about teh cost of the first two films if bought seperately so how can you go wrong?
One of the best Anthology's EVER! I really enjoy the Alien(s) movies. I recommend this product if you enjoy the Aliens movies.

In apce no one can hear you scream. The first two "alien" movies are true classics and merit the five stars in reviewing but Alien #3 is an embarrassment. Alien #4 is slightly better but it still doesn't make it.
Some other Classic movie, with good quality of restoration in audio and image, it worth the price..... It has better  package than others i've seen before, and include great extras...

A wonderful package that feels very together and has some nice art, makes me feel like a true Alien fan, looks nice sitting on movie rack, 2 of the best sci-fi films of all time are in this package, it's a pretty good deal
Worth every penny! lot's of behind the scenes footage from all four movie. The chest busting scene in Alien is one of the greatest moments in movie history.

Items were found on my doorstep the next day. The box it came it was still closed, or appeared not to have been opened.

So beautiful!  Watching these movies for the first time since I was a child, I could barely remember them.  Visually stunning movies that were decades ahead of the game. It's all the movies.  I do not know what more to say about it than that so have a nice day.

This has great quality packaging, really a nice set for a great price. I would recommend this to anyone looking to buy a gift for a science fiction fan.

The best of the best, blu-ray DVD clarity brought out more detail in the films than I've ever seen before.  Add the suspense and excellent directing, which makes this set a must have for every science fiction/"Alien" film-buff.
Amazing series of films, particularly #2 and #1 (in that order), and the amount of bonus content this set comes with is ridiculous. Highly recommend.
surprising and very well done packaging for some of the best movies ever made.  a great set with lots of extra features and superb transfer onto Blu-ray.  very worth purchasing NOW!!!

I simply love the Alien movies so there is not really much I can say. The product is nicely packaged and the commentaries are great.

If you can get this set on sale like I did it's definitely worth it. Only way i'd ever purchase "Resurrection"

Very well put together package - nothing more I'd ask from this set...well other than 3 & 4 be better movies!
a perfect gift for Alien lovers! this is a very nice set. includes all the movies, and two discs with extra stuff. Buy it! Great price!

Ordered this during the black friday sale. Received it today but the first three movies have bad scratches on them. The third looks like someone scraped over concrete with the disc! Cardboard sleeve packaging = damaged discs. I am returning for a refund and buying the single discs which are still on sale. Check your discs after purchasing if you get this set.

bought this for my husband as a gift. The packaging is amazing,as is the quality of the movies ! He is thrilled to finally have them on blu-ray !!! This is an excellent set and I would have paid twice as much to see the smile on his face.
Amazing set! Just what i was looking for. You get all the Alien Movies 1-4 plus the making of all the movies, plus a bunch of extras. If you love the series this is a must have!!!

Classic quad of movies and just when you think they make one sequel too many, you make Alien Resurrection and it is AWESOME!!  Sigourney Weaver maintains an amazing character in these movies.  The best part is how she becomes emotilaly void and harder as the sequels continue.  Great job on these movies.

I was very excited about this set at the price until the second film, Aliens, would not play. Amazon issued me a new set and again it would not play. After some research I realized that this is an all region import, from where I do not know, but all region discs are notorious for having playback problems in many North America players. I am sending mine back for a refund and you should be very careful to be sure any discs you buy say region 1 or A in North America. Too bad too because there are a lot of extras, although the transfers on the other films are not so good but then again it's not an official north american release and not subject to the same standards.

All of Alien's movies in Blu Ray!!!  I really like this compilation.  These movies have been cleaned up and even have the director's cuts on some.  I really only cared for the first and second movie but having all of these is worth it.  Highly recommended.

I'm so glad I decided to purchase these films in box set instead of just the individual ones I like. The extra footage around the making of the film, especially the original, was very exciting (and there is A LOT of extra behind-the-scenes info to know about). I also really like the packaging, it's well made and slim enough to fit nicely on any media shelf. As for the movies, 1 & 2 are my favorites (I'm pretty sure I can recite Aliens by heart) but it was more cost effective to have the whole set. And this way I get to give the last two a few more views. There wasn't a behind-the-scenes on the 4th one, which I thought was interesting, but this is a product that delivers and at an amazing sale price for blu-ray!
It is everything I wanted it to be... from the booklet photos to the behind the scenes content on the disk.

I had wanted this blu-ray collection ever since it was first revealed and released. I had to wait awhile, because like many, I can't afford everything I want. Black Friday and holiday sales is the best way to go sometimes. The movies look gorgeous and there's just an extensive array of special features, the value is just there.

I know Alien Resurrection is looked upon very poorly, but I enjoyed it much more than Alien 3 (the sole terrible Fincher movie, but it wasn't his fault). Ron Perlman was great in it, and it's just a fun time. Sure, its arguable some of that may have been unintentional, but the same director made Amelie, The City of Lost Children and Delicatessen. I've watched Aliens more than all the others combined probably. James Cameron was just at the top of his game as he made his way to king of the world. Once you're at the top, you have nowhere to go but down. I don't look upon the first Alien as highly as others, but horror isn't my most favorite of genres.

Even if you like only one of these movies, especially if you love the first or the second or both, this set is the PREMIERE version to own.
Keeps you up at night after watching. Big SW fan. Reserection is a good finale. Worth the money. Bye Bye

You cannot go wrong with this set. Absolutely gorgeous packaging and a crapload of bonus content. The menus are loaded with details of each specific movie and you can just spend your time looking at them. The quality of the movies itself is a HUGE leap from previously released DVD version, especially with Aliens. Would I have paid the original $70 that it cost? Probably not. Should you get it for $25? Hell to the YES.

Stunning set - definitely a "must have" for an Alien movie fan.  I have not seen movies 1, 2, and 3 for a long time, but I was so thrilled to see all of these movies again.  The packaging is GREAT, a nice "book" with very cool art and the DVD's are well spaced out.  The movies are just the best if you are a Sci Fi fan of movies like these.  I'm really glad I went ahead with these.

The packaging is impressive, small footprint but high quality graphics.  Patience is needed to play the movies.  The message that my blue ray player might need to download new software came up each time I started to play a new disc.  Waiting a minute or so would result in the message screen disappearing and the movie beginning. I have only tried each disc once so I don't know if this will repeat every time.

This Box Set of the Alien Anthology had a big issue at the time of its release being made for newer blue ray players. The player updates weren't even available either so many people found (as I did) unplayable. It was months later that I was able to get an update that allowed the discs to play. Now of course all blue ray players will play this set just fine. It features an option to binge watch the four movies skipping menus and home screens. If you got the time it's a fun ride.
Love! I already had an extended version of the Alien trilogy, but I bought this one because it was not only blu-ray, but it had soooo many extras!!! Very happy with this one!

I am a huge Alien and Predator fan. This Alien Boxset is awesome. The quality of the prints are impressive and well as the sound. These films stand up against anything you put in front of them. They have often been imitated but never duplicated. If you have seen them before, see them again. If you haven't seen them before here is your opportunity to do so. This Alien Boxset if in my top five sci-fi boxsets that I own. You can't lose if this set is what you choose. Cheers

The most complete and comprehensive set on Alien movies imaginable.
The Alien "Anthology" (a much classier word than "Quadrilogy". Yuck.) is brought to blu ray with class and gusto.
The transfer on the first two films are demo disc quality. Alien looks as good as Blade Runner does, and that movie is in my top ten blu rays of all time. Aliens is nearly as powerful with little holding it back from being a damn good transfer in it's own right.
Fans of 1 & 2 won't be disappointed with this completionist set. Even if you don't care for 3 and 4, the extras native to this pack are worth it. Especially since I've seen prices for this pack drop under $40.
This set made me capitulate and give Alien 3 a rewatch on it's alternate cut. The Assembly Cut I believe.
Which is actually a blu ray exclusive in and of itself. On the DVD sets, it was a workprint cut. Not as refined, still kinda choppy.
It's been cleaned up and given the red carpet treatment here which is amazing, because it makes the movie better. Not only better, it justifies the movie's existence. Alien 3 is now a personal favorite.
The impact of this blu ray set actually changed my mind about a movie- for the better. The enlightening making of documentaries surrounding each film are also amazing, but none more so than Alien 3. The troubled production, chronicled (more or less) unbiasedly in "Wreckage and Rage" might be the unsung gem of this set. It offers a look inside the messed up production of the sequel to one of the most loved sci-fi movies ever. Stress and pressure for ages behind the scenes of this movie, it's bound to give you a new perspective on Alien 3 and why it could've been every bit as good as Alien and Aliens.
Fear not, the all-encompassing behind the scenes and making of's are just as in-depth for each movie without exception.
Even for the much maligned Alien Resurrection, you might be shocked at how interesting the special features are.
No movie was shortchanged in this set, and for fans it's a must own.
It has become a quintessential blu ray set in my collection, and one that I'm beyond proud to own.

Wanted these movies last year, but they were out of them durig the sale at Best Buy.  After knowing the sale I missed, I just couldn't pay full price for them, so I have never gotten them, til now.  Feel like I got a deal with this price

What is there to say? It's still one of the best Blu-ray sets ever produced. The supplemental materials are exhaustive. The first two films look like they were made today. If you have a Blu-ray player, you simply don't have a choice -- you have to own this.

It's fun to get a peek behind the curtain and see how these movies were made.  There were two versions of each of the four movies, theatrical release and a director's cut.
